name: Best Stuffed Cabbage Rolls
description: Tender leaves of cabbage are wrapped around a hearty sirloin and rice filling and topped with a homemade tomato sauce in this family-friendly recipe for stuffed cabbage leaves. The hint of allspice and slight tang from vinegar create a perfect balance in this dish. They remind me of eating at a Lebanese food festival, although not quite as spicy. Serve with Greek salad or tabouli salad and warm pita for the perfect bite!
recipeIngredient: 1 (14 ounce) can petite diced tomatoes, undrained
2 teaspoons chopped fresh parsley, or to taste

recipeInstructions.text: Bring a large pot of water to a boil. Stir in 4 teaspoons salt. Remove loose, outer leaves from the cabbage and place in the boiling water for 1 minute. Remove from the water and set aside.

Remove core from the cabbage and carefully place the head in the boiling water. Cook for 5 minutes, removing the outer leaves one at a time as they loosen every minute. Set aside 12 large leaves and reserve inner portion of the cabbage for another use.

Heat oil in a medium saucepan over medium heat. Set aside 2 tablespoons minced onion for cabbage rolls; add remaining onion to the hot oil. Cook, stirring often, until translucent, about 2 minutes. Stir in tomato sauce, undrained diced tomatoes, water, vinegar, 1/2 teaspoon pepper, and 1/2 teaspoon salt; bring to a simmer. Reduce heat to low and cook for 10 minutes.
Meanwhile, preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
Prepare cabbage rolls: Mix sirloin, rice, garlic, reserved minced onion, remaining 1 1/2 teaspoons salt, remaining pepper, and allspice together in a bowl until well combined.

Place a softened cabbage leaf on a cutting board and remove the bottom, tough portion of the stem. Place about 3 tablespoons meat filling into the center of the leaf. Fold the sides inward and roll the leaf up tightly, like a burrito or spring roll. Repeat with remaining leaves and filling.
Pour 1 cup tomato sauce mixture in a bottom of a 9x13-inch or 11x7-inch baking dish. Place cabbage rolls, seam-side down, in the baking dish and pour remaining sauce on top. Cover tightly with foil.
Bake in preheated oven for 1 hour. Lightly squeeze a wedge of lemon over each serving and garnish with parsley.

review.reviewBody: 6.27.21  I’ve made a lot of stuffed cabbage recipes, and this is a good one.  The only thing I did differently was put the whole head of cabbage in the freezer several days ago, defrosted it, cut the core out, and the leaves just fall off.  They’ll be wet, but I just drain them, and wipe each leaf with a paper towel.  This is a method I found in a cookbook called The Cabbage King, and I’ve been doing it this way for years (just easier).  Cooked 6 rolls last night, and put the other half in the freezer. (uncooked) for a quick weeknight meal.  I know oven temperatures can vary and mine be running a bit hot, but the filling overcooked on the rolls.  In the future, I’ll start checking for doneness at 45 minutes.  I’ll probably add a few red pepper flakes to the sauce next time, but that’s personal taste.  Stuffed cabbage rolls are a bit of work, but they’re worth the effort.  Served with mashed potatoes and green beans.  This one’s a keeper.

By far tastiest cabbage roll recipe!  The tomato sauce and chopped tomatoes add body and sweetness, as well as enough sauciness to make this a super delicious dish.  I’ll try steaming the whole cabbage first, as I did experience some tearing of the leaves.  It’s a challenge having enough large leaves to make good sized rolls,
